summary: This document is an email chain between Assistant U.S. Attorney Maurene Comey and defense attorney Laura Menninger regarding discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case. It details the government's plan to produce thousands of images from Epstein's devices, address deficiencies in prior productions, and arrange for the defense to review highly confidential evidence in Colorado and New York.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Partner at Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She is corresponding with the prosecution about discovery deficiencies, specifically regarding the review and production of images and videos from Epstein's devices.

persons.name: Maurene Comey
persons.context: Prosecutor for the Southern District of New York handling the U.S. v. Maxwell case. She is coordinating with the FBI and the defense to facilitate discovery, including de-designating confidential materials and arranging evidence reviews.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: CC'd on the email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case, likely involved in the legal or paralegal support team.

persons.name: Bobbi Sternheim
persons.context: CC'd on the email correspondence regarding discovery issues in the Maxwell case, likely part of the defense or prosecution legal team.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The accused in the case U.S. v. Maxwell. The correspondence concerns the discovery materials to be provided to her and her defense team, including images and videos seized from Epstein's residences.

persons.name: Chris
persons.context: Mentioned in an email as having discussed with Maurene Comey the issue of partially recovered email attachments from Epstein's devices.

connections.description: Laura Menninger is the defense attorney representing Ghislaine Maxwell in the criminal case.
Prosecutor and defense attorney corresponding about discovery issues in the U.S. v. Maxwell case.
The AUSA is working with the FBI to review, de-designate, and transfer evidence (images, videos, boots) for the Maxwell case.
Both are CC'd on the discovery correspondence, indicating they are part of the legal teams involved in the case.
The evidence being discussed (images from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence) directly links Maxwell to Epstein's activities.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date for U.S. v. Maxwell
events.description: The trial for Ghislaine Maxwell was scheduled to begin on November 29, 2021.

events.title: Defense Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Laura Menninger traveled to New York to review evidence, including highly confidential images and videos on government hard drives.

events.title: FBI Report on Digital Evidence
events.description: An FBI report indicated approximately 33,747 highly confidential images and 895 highly confidential videos were identified from a digital review of CART-processed evidence from Epstein's devices.

events.title: Discovery Production and Transfer Coordination
events.description: AUSA Comey outlines plan to produce de-designated images, transfer hard drives and boots to Colorado for defense review, and arrange for photo review in New York.

locations: 500 Pearl (likely a government building in NYC)
1 St. Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (SDNY Office)
150 10th Avenue, Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman office)
keyFacts: The FBI had completed a de-designation review, reclassifying thousands of images from 'Highly Confidential' to 'Confidential' for production to the defense.
Approximately 40,000 images were extracted from CDs seized from Jeffrey Epstein's New York residence.

The government maintained a category of 'Highly Confidential' material defined as containing 'nude, partially-nude, or otherwise sexualized images, videos, or other depictions of individuals,' which required in-person review under supervision.

Significant discrepancies existed between the number of 'Highly Confidential' files verbally conveyed to the defense (~2,100) and the number indicated in an FBI report (~34,000 total HC images/videos).

The defense faced major technical hurdles in reviewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, unreadable file formats, and incomplete productions to the client at the MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center).
